ARTICLE XXV. GENERAL PENALTY; CITATIONS*
----------
*Editor's note--Ord. No. O-13-88, §2, adopted Feb. 8, 1987, renumbered Ch. 12, Art. XXIV as Art.
XXV.
----------
Sec. 12-295. Definitions.
(a) The word "officer" shall mean the health officer and inspectors or agents of the health officer.
(b) The word "person" includes a natural person, firm, partnership, association, sole proprietorship, or
corporation, as well as any agents, representatives or employees thereof upon whom responsibility or liability is
imposed by this code for the violation cited. (Ord. No. O-173-86, §1, 12-22-86)
Sec. 12-296. Citation and settlement in lieu of prosecution for certain offenses.
Whenever an officer observes a violation of certain provisions of this code as specified in section 12-
299 of this chapter or has probable cause to believe that such a violation has occurred and that a particular
person is responsible, said officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, issue the alleged violator a
citation which shall:
(1) Advise said person that the same has violated a specified ordinance.
(2) Request said person to make payment in an amount applicable to said alleged violation as set
forth in section 12-299 as settlement of said claim.
(3) Advise said person, where applicable, to cease and/or abate said violation forthwith and to
refrain from like violations in the future.
(4) Inform said person that, upon failure to settle the claim and to cease and/or abate said
violations, a complaint will be filed with the Circuit Court of Cook County.
(Ord. No. O-173-86, §1, 12-22-86)
Sec. 12-297. Service of citation.
Citations as provided by section 12-296 of this chapter shall be personally served upon the person
responsible for the violation, his agent, representative, independent contractor, or employee. In the event the
owner, occupant, contractor, or other person responsible for the violation cannot be located, the citation may be
served by posting a copy at the property, structure or vehicle where the violation has occurred and sending a
copy certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of such person. (Ord. No. O-173-86,
§1, 12-22-86)
Sec. 12-298. Settlement of claim.
(a) Any person served with a citation pursuant to section 12-297 may settle and compromise the
violation claim in respect of such ordinance violation and paying to the village the applicable amount as shown
and within the time period set forth in the schedule set forth in section 12-299 of this chapter.
(b) In the event that payment is not made within the time prescribed and a complaint has been filed in
the Circuit Court of Cook County, payment of any fine and costs shall be in such amounts as may be
determined by and established by the Circuit Court of Cook County within the limits established by this Code.
(Ord. No. O-173-86, §1, 12-22-86)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12

ARTICLE XXVI. REGULATION OF LIGHTING*
----------
*Editor's note--Ordinance No. O-109-89, adopted Aug. 14, 1989, amended Ch. 12 by adding a new
Art. XXVI consisting of provisions numbered §§12-300--12-306. In order to conform to established Code
format, and in order to provide possible future expansion of Art. XXV without the necessity of pointnumbering,
the editor has renumbered these new provisions as §§12-310--12-316. The original section
numbers of these provisions have been preserved in the history notes following each section and in the Code
Comparative Table at the back of this volume in order to aid the user in tracking.
Cross reference(s)--Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 16; street lighting requirements in subdivisions, App.
B, §8.09.
----------
Sec. 12-310. Definitions.
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article:
Flood light. A luminare designed so that at least ninety (90) percent of the emitted light is within an
angle of thirty (30) degrees to the centerline of the light beam.
Foot lambert. One (1) foot lambert is the brightness of a perfectly diffusing surface uniformly emitting
or reflecting one (1) lumen per square foot of surface.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-42
Footcandle. One (1) footcandle is the amount of illumination provided by a light source of one (1)
international candle at a distance of one (1) foot from the light source.
International candle or candle power. One (1) international candle is the unit of luminous intensity as
established by standard light sources as maintained by the U.S. Bureau of Standards. This is more commonly
called one (1) candle power.
Lumen. One (1) lumen is that quantity of luminous energy included in one (1) steradian unit solid
angle from a uniform point source of one (1) candle power. It is also defined as the luminous flux intercepted
by a surface of one (1) square foot, all points of which are one (1) foot from a uniform point source of one (1)
candle power.
Luminare. A device or fixture containing a light source and means for directing and controlling the
distribution of light emitted therefrom. (Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-300), 8-14-89)
Sec. 12-311. Regulations of intensity of light.
It is unlawful for any person, association or other legal entity owning, occupying or controlling any
property within the Village of Palatine to exceed the following light intensity regulations:
(1) No lighting source shall cause more than one-tenth (0.1) footcandle of illumination to fall on
adjoining R1, R1A, R1B, R1C and R2 residentially zoned property and any property zoned P
or PUD which is improved with one (1) or more single-family detached dwellings.
(2) No lighting source shall cause more than two-tenths (0.2) footcandle of illumination to fall on
adjoining R3 or R3A residential property and any property zoned P or PUD which is
improved multifamily property.
(3) No lighting source shall cause more than two (2) footcandles of illumination to fall on any
adjoining commercially zoned property and any property zoned P or PUD which is improved
commercial property.
(4) No lighting source shall cause more than five (5) footcandles of illumination to fall on any
public way in commercially zoned property.(Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-301), 8-14-89)
Sec. 12-312. Regulations on glare.
Regulations on glare shall be as follows:
(1) No floodlight shall be mounted higher than twenty-five (25) feet above the ground nor shall
any part of any floodlight's beam strike the ground at any angle of more than forty-five (45)
degrees from vertical.
(2) No light source shall present a surface brightness when viewed between horizontal and an
angle of forty-five (45) degrees above horizontal from adjoining property in accordance with
the following:
a. 750 foot lamberts from R1, R1A, R1B, R1C and R2 zoned property.
b. 1,500 foot lamberts from R3 and R3A zoned property.
c. 2,200 foot lamberts from any commercially zoned property.
d. 10,000 foot lamberts from any public way.
(Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-302), 8-14-89)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-43
Sec. 12-313. Standards of measurement.
(a) Light intensity shall be measured in footcandles with a direct reading portable low range light meter
having a range of zero to twenty (0--20) footcandles. Values set forth in this article are maximum values
measured at ninety (90) degrees to the incidence of light from the source.
(b) Measurement methods and techniques shall be those recommended by the Illuminating
Engineering Society in their "Standard Methods for Measuring and Reporting Horizontal Footcandle."
(c) Brightness measurement based on foot lambert must be governed by the definition of the foot
lambert and lumen. Calculated values for source brightness may be obtained by using comparable
measurement techniques. Calculations shall be in accordance with the following:
(1) Spherical bare sources (incandescent lamps). The brightness shall be calculated as total
lumens divided by one-tenth the square of the diameter of the source measured in inches.
(2) Cylindrical bare sources (fluorescent lamps). The brightness shall be calculated as total
lumens divided by one-fiftieth the product of length and diameter of the source in inches.
(3) Floodlight sources. The brightness of floodlight sources shall be calculated as the eight-tenths
of the total lumens divided by the area of the face of the floodlight in square feet.
If the light source is mounted in a diffuse luminare, seven-tenths of the above values shall be
used.
The values of lumens to be used shall be based on the following efficiencies:
Incandescent Filament Lamps
Gaseous Discharge Lamps
25 watt-- 250 lumens
40 watts-- 1,200 lumens
40 watt-- 500 lumens
100 watts-- 3,000 lumens
60 watt-- 800 lumens
250 watts--11,000 lumens
100 watt-- 1,600 lumens
400 watts--25,000 lumens
200 watt-- 3,300 lumens
1,000 watts--65,000 lumens
300 watt-- 5,000 lumens
500 watt-- 9,000 lumens
1,000 watt—20,000 lumens
(Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-303), 8-14-89)
Sec. 12-314. Enforcement.
Any existing lighting condition determined by the director of environmental health to be in violation of
any of the provisions of this article shall, within the time determined on a written notice to the violator, be
corrected. Service of notice may be made by personal service, publication in a local newspaper generally
circulated within the village, conspicuous posting on the premises where the violation occurs or by U.S. mail.
(Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-304), 8-14-89)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-44
Sec. 12-315. Hearing of variations.
Where practical difficulties or particular hardship, not created by any person having interest in the
property, prevents carrying out the strict letter of any of the provisions of this article, the board of health, on
petition, may determine and vary the requirements of this article to the extent that they are still in harmony with
its general purpose and intent. However, any such variation shall be made by the board as specified only after a
hearing before the board, of which hearing there shall be notice of time and place of the hearing given by
publication not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days before said hearing, and also by
United States mail addressed to the person(s) or entity seeking a variation from the requirements of this article
and the owners of any adjacent property. (Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-305), 8-14-89)
Sec. 12-316. Violations declared a nuisance.
The failure of persons owning or occupying the property to abate any lighting violation(s), as stated in
this article, is declared a public nuisance and shall be subject to the abatement provisions of Article XXII of
this chapter and the penalty provisions of Article XXIII of chapter. (Ord. No. O-109-89, §1 (12-306), 8-14-89)
ARTICLE XXVII. GRAFFITI
Sec. 12-317. Graffiti Prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property to not remove or paint over any prohibited sign painted
directly on an exterior wall of a building or on any structure upon that property. A prohibited sign includes but
is not limited to any permanent display of any letter, numeral, figure, emblem, insignia, picture, outline,
character, spectacle, delineation, announcement or any combination thereof which are painted of a color
different from the color of the exterior of the structure on which it is painted and which are viable beyond the
boundaries of the property including signs commonly known as graffiti. A painted area on the side of a
structure used to cover a prohibited sign or graffiti which is of a different color or surface material than the
remaining exterior surface of that side of the structure is unlawful.
Sec. 12-318. Failure to remove graffiti declared a nuisance.
The failure of an owner of property to remove from the exterior of structures upon the owner's property any
permanent display of a prohibited sign or graffiti in compliance with the regulations of this Code, within
fourteen (14) days of notification, is declared a public nuisance and shall be subject to the abatement
provisions of Article XXII of this chapter and the penalty provisions of Article XXIII of this Chapter. (Ord.
No. 0-60-93 6-14-93)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-45
ARTICLE XXVIII. DRUG PARAPHERNALIA
Sec. 12-319. Definitions.
As used herein, unless the context requires otherwise.
Cannabis. The term ”cannabis” shall include marijuana, hashish and other substances which are
identified as including any parts of the plan Cannabis Sativa, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any
part of such plant, whether growing or not, and any compound, manufacture, salt derivative, mixture or
preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol
derivatives.
Controlled Substance. The term ”controlled substance” shall have the meaning ascribed to it in
Section 102 of the ”Illinois Controlled Substances Act”
(720 ILCS 570/102), as if that definition were incorporated herein.
Deliver or Delivery. The terms “deliver” or “delivery” mean the actual, constructive or attempted
transfer of possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship.
Drug Paraphernalia. The term ”drug paraphernalia” means all equipment, products and materials of
any kind which are peculiar to and marketed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting,
manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging,
repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the
human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the Cannabis Control Act, the Illinois Controlled
Substances Act, or Palatine Ordinance Section 12-29. Possession of marijuana prohibited. Drug Paraphernalia
includes, but is not limited to:
1. Kits peculiar to and marketed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing,
processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled substance.
2. Isomerization devices peculiar to and marketed for use in increasing the potency of any
species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled substance.
3. Testing equipment peculiar to and marketed for private home use in identifying or in
analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis or controlled substance.
4. Diluents and adulterants peculiar to and marketed for cutting cannabis or a controlled
substance by private persons.
5. Objects peculiar to and marketed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing
cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body including, where applicable,
the following items:
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-46
a. water pipes
b. carburetion tubes, pipes and devices
c. smoking and carburetion masks
d. miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials
e. electric pipes
f. air-driven pipes
g. chillums
h. bongs
I. ice pipes or chillers
j. roach clips
6. Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of
this Ordinance.
Sec. 12-320. Sale or Delivery of Drug Paraphernalia
(a) It is unlawful for any person to keep for sale, offer for sale, sell, or deliver for any commercial
consideration any item of drug paraphernalia.
(b) Any store, place, or premises from which or in which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept
for sale, offered for sale, sold, or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared a public nuisance.
Sec. 12-321. Possession of drug paraphernalia
(a) It is unlawful for any person to knowingly possess an item of drug paraphernalia with the
intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance into the
human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use.
(b) In determining intent under subsection (a), the trier of fact may take into consideration the
proximity of the cannabis or controlled substance to drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis or
controlled substance on the drug paraphernalia.
Sec. 12-322. Exempt items
(a) Items marketed for use in lawful research, teaching or chemical analysis of cannabis and not
for sale
(b) Items marketed for, or historically and customarily used in connection with the use of tobacco
or any other lawful substance, to include, but not limited to, garden hoses, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco
pipes, and cigarette rolling papers.
(c) Items used for decorative purposes providing such items have been rendered completely
inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purposes prohibited in this Ordinance.
Sec. 12-323. Forfeiture and seizure of prohibited property
(a) All drug paraphernalia is subject to forfeiture.
(b) Property subject to forfeiture may be seized by any police officer upon process issued by a
court having jurisdiction.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-47
(c) Seizures may be made by police officers if there is probable cause to believe that the property
has been used to introduce cannabis or a controlled substance into the human body, or has cannabis or a
controlled substance on it, including its residue, or is dangerous to health or safety and existing circumstances
do not allow reasonable time for the officer to obtain lawful process.
(d) The presence of items which are deemed violative of this Ordinance or are otherwise subject to
its forfeiture provisions in an inventory shall not subject the entire inventory to seizure or forfeiture.
(e) When property is seized under this Ordinance, the Chief of Police may have the property
removed to a place designated by him.
(f) The Circuit Court shall determine the validity of any seizures made under this Ordinance and
determine the disposition of all seized property.
(g) When property is forfeited under this Ordinance, the Chief of Police may retain the property
for official use or have the property destroyed.
Sec. 12-324. Penalty
Any person who is found guilty of violating section 12-320 or 12-321 shall be subject to a fine of not
less than two hundred ($200.00) dollars nor more than one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars for each separate
occurrence
ARTICLE XXIX. CONFLICTS WITH CERTAIN HOME RULE
COUNTY ORDINANCES
------------
Editor’s Note: Article XXIX was adopted by Ord. #O-50-17 on 5/1/17
A. Employers located within the Village shall comply with all applicable Federal and/or State
laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time with regard to
both the payment of minimum hourly wages and paid sick leave. Employee eligibility for paid
sick leave and minimum hourly wages shall also be in compliance with all applicable Federal
and/or State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time.
B. No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave, or minimum hourly wages, including,
without limitation, any additional obligations by Ordinances adopted by the County of Cook
Board of Commissioners, including but not limited to file numbers 16-4229 and 16-5768,
shall apply to employers located within the Village, except those required by Federal and/or
State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time.
C. For the purposes of this Section, the term “employee” means an individual permitted to work
by an employer regardless of the number of persons the employer employs, and the term
“employer” means any person employing one or more employees, or seeking to employ one or
more employees, if the person has its principal place of business within the Village or does
business within the Village.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 12
OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
12-48
D. For the purposes of this Section, the term “employer” does not mean:
(a) The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the
government of the United States;
(b) An Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe;
(c) The government of the State or any agency or department thereof; or
(d) The government of any municipality.”
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 13 - POLICE DEPARTMENT
13-1
Chapter 13 POLICE DEPARTMENT*
----------
*Editor's note--Ord. No. O-108-76, 1, enacted Dec. 13, 1976, repealed former Ch. 13, relative to
the police department, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Ch. 13, pertaining to the same subject matter. Former
Ch. 13 was derived from Code 1961, 5.001--5.016.
Cross reference(s)--Police and fire commission. 2-361 et seq.
----------
Editor’s Note: Ordinance 0-16-02 passed on 1/28/02 replaced Secs. 13-1 through 13-8.
-----------------------
Sec. 13-1. Creation; composition.
There is hereby created a police department for the Village of Palatine which shall consist of a chief of police
and as many employees as the Corporate Authorities may designate from time to time. (Ord. No. O-108-76,
§1, 12-13-76) (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-1.1. Reserved. (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Editor's note--Section 13-1.1, pertaining to agreements for police services for state and federally owned
facilities located in the village, and derived from Ord. No. O-180-88, ' 2, adopted Dec. 27, 1988, was deleted
by Ord. No. O-88-91, §1, adopted June 24, 1991. (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-2. Appointment and removal of the chief of police.
The chief of police shall be appointed by the village manager with the approval by a majority vote of the
Corporate Authorities.. The person appointed as chief of police must have achieved a baccalaureate degree
from an accredited college or university prior to the date of appointment. The chief of police shall serve at the
pleasure of the village manager and may be removed by the village manager at any time thereafter. (Ord. No.
O-108-76. §1, 12-13-76; Ord. No. O-4-86, §1, 1-13-86) (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-3. Supervision and control of the chief of police.
The village manager shall be the immediate supervisor of the chief of police, and all policies, directives and
orders from the village to the chief of police shall be made by or transmitted through the village manager. The
chief of police shall report directly to the village manager and not to the Mayor and Village Council or to
individual members thereof. (Ord. No. O-108-76, §1, 12-13-76) (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-4. Powers and duties of the police chief generally.
The chief of police shall direct the administration and operation of the police department and in addition to
policies transmitted to him by the village manager, shall establish such other policies, directives, rules and
regulations for the administration and operation of the department as he sees fit, and provided in written form
to all employees. The chief of police shall have the authority and responsibility for fiscal management of the
police department within the fiscal policies and procedures established by the village manager and Corporate
Authorities. The chief of police shall serve as appointing authority for appointment to any position within the
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 13 - POLICE DEPARTMENT
13-2
department other than his own, and shall have the power to suspend, demote or dismiss any employee, subject
to and in accordance with the provisions of this Code governing the fire and police commission, Chapter 2,
Article XX, and the village work rules. (Ord. No. O-108-76, §1, 12-13-76; Ord. No. O-4-86, §1, 1-13-86)
(Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-5. Civil service exempt command positions.
The chief of police, with the concurrence of the village manager, shall have the authority to recruit and appoint
individuals to civil service exempt command positions within the department. Civil service exempt command
positions will not have certified status and rights. Individuals appointed to exempt command positions shall
serve at the pleasure of the chief of police and may be removed by the chief with concurrence of the village
manager at any time thereafter. If an individual is appointed to such a position who holds certified status within
the department in another position, the individual shall retain a guaranteed right to return to the former position
with certified status upon termination from the exempt command position, subject to section 2-380 of this
Code. (Ord. No. O-108-76, §1, 12-13-76) (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-6. Dismissals.
No full-time, certified member of the police department, except the police chief, shall be dismissed until after a
hearing by the fire and police commission, in accordance with its rules and the provisions of Chapter 13 of this
Code. The chief of police, without the requirement of a hearing shall have the power to dismiss a patrol officer
who is serving in an original appointment probationary period. (Ord. No. O-108-76, §1, 12-13-76) (Ord. No.
0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-7. Residency requirement for all police officers.
All persons who are appointed police officers of the village of Palatine shall maintain residence in one of the
following Illinois Counties: Cook, DuPage, Kane, McHenry, or Lake. (Ord. No. O-136-77, §1, 12-27-77;
Ord. No. 0-97-94 §1, 7-25-94) (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-8. Auxiliary police unit. Intentionally omitted. (Ord. No. 0-16-02 §4, 1/28/02)
Sec. 13-9. Disposition of abandoned property.
(a) Office of property custodian created. There hereby is created a property custodian for the village,
who may be an officer of the police department, appointed by and to serve at the pleasure of the chief of police,
or a civilian employee whose appointment shall be approved by the chief of police and who shall serve at the
pleasure of the chief of police.
(b) Duties of property custodian. The property custodian shall act as custodian of all personal property
seized, taken, or otherwise transferred to the possession of the police department. All officers and members of
the department into whose possession may be transferred any such personal property shall deliver the same
promptly to the property custodian, unless it is needed for immediate use as evidence, in which case, a report
and inventory of the same shall be forwarded promptly to the property custodian. Provided, however, that
nothing herein contained shall be deemed to require the property custodian to take possession or make
disposition of any lost or stolen property, the possession or disposition of which is otherwise provided for by
this Code.
(c) Custody and disposition of personal property. The property custodian shall maintain a complete
and accurate record of all personal property which may be seized or otherwise transferred to the possession of
the police department and shall make reasonable efforts to identify and notify the owner or other person
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 13 - POLICE DEPARTMENT
13-3
entitled to possession thereof, and shall return the property after such person provides satisfactory proof of
ownership or right to possession and reimburse the police department for reasonable expenses and costs.
If the identity or location of the owner or other person entitled to possession of such personal property
has not been ascertained within sixty (60) days after the police department obtains possession thereof, the
property custodian shall proceed to dispose of said personal property. If such personal property is deemed
saleable, the property custodian shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the
village a notice of sale, his intent to sell the same at public auction for cash, describing it in general terms and
not by individual item. Thereupon, such personal property will be sold at public auction at such place as the
chief of police may direct in such manner as to expose to the inspection of the bidders all such personal
property so offered for sale. Property offered, but not sold, at such auction may be offered and sold at a
subsequent public auction without such notice.
If any such personal property is deemed to be of use to any village department, such property may be
retained for use of such department upon approval of the village manager. Any such personal property deemed
by the property custodian to be unsaleable shall be confiscated or destroyed. The proceeds of any sale or sales
so made, after deducting the cost of storage, advertising, and other expenses incident to the handling and sale
of such property, shall be paid by the property custodian to the Village of Palatine finance director who shall
deposit said proceeds in the general fund of the village.
(d) Exception; weapons. The preceding provision of this section shall not apply to pistols, revolvers,
knives, dirks, slingshots, metallic knuckles, or other deadly weapons of like character. All such weapons,
except those that the chief of police shall order retained for the use of the police department, shall be presented
to the chief of police by the property custodian, within one year after their receipt, for destruction.
(e) Perishable property. Any personal property seized or transferred to the possession of the police
department which is of a perishable nature so as to make it dangerous or inadvisable to retain possession
thereof for the length of time specified in the preceding subsections, the property custodian upon certifying
such fact to the chief of police and setting forth his reason why such property should not be retained for the
period hereinabove fixed, and with the approval of the chief of police, shall cause such property, if deemed by
the property custodian to be saleable, to be advertised forthwith in a newspaper of general circulation within
the village and shall sell such personal property at public auction at any time after three (3) days have elapsed
from the seizure or taking possession thereof; provided, however, that any such personal property deemed to be
unsaleable or dangerous shall be disposed of as refuse or in other reasonable manner as the chief of police shall
direct. (Ord. No. O-16-79, 1, 3-12-79)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14 - REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURE ACT
14-1
Chapter 14 REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURE ACT*
----------
*Editor's note--Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, enacted July 14, 1980, amended this Code by deleting former
Ch. 14, relative to real estate disclosure, and enacting in lieu thereof a new Ch. 14 pertaining to the same
subject matter. Former Ch. 14 was derived from Code 1961, 28.101, 28.201--28.206, 28.301--28.303,
28.401--28.404, 28.502, 28.601--28.603; Ord. No. O-1-79, 4, adopted Jan. 8, 1979; Ord. No. O-92-79, 5,
adopted July 9, 1979.
----------
Art. I. In General, 14-1--14-15
Art. II. Disclosure of Interests, 14-16--14-35
Art. III. Disclosure Notices, 14-36--14-50
Art. IV. Condemnation Proceedings, 14-51--14-80
Art. V. Violation; Penalty, 14-81--14-83
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. Definitions.
For the purposes of this chapter the following words shall have the meanings indicated unless their
context clearly requires otherwise:
Contract means any agreement concerning real estate including but not limited to the purchase, sale,
lease, license, trading, granting of easements, gifts, air rights, mineral rights, oil or gas rights, options, or
contracts to purchase.
Disclosure notice means the writing provided in section 14-36.
Interest in real estate means any holder of the legal title, equitable title, beneficial interest, direct or
indirect financial interest, leasehold, lien, tax sale certificate, option, or any other interest whatsoever
concerning the real estate, any right to receive rents or proceeds from real estate, any interest in a land trust,
including that of beneficiary, or person entitled under the law to make a claim to any portion of a
condemnation award pursuant to a judgment order.
Land trust means any express agreement or arrangement whereof a use, confidence or trust is declared
of any real estate or of any charge upon real estate, for the use or benefit of any person, public body, corporate
or other entity, under which the title to real property, both legal and equitable, is held by a trustee, subject only
to the execution of the trust, which may be enforced by the beneficiaries, and under which the interest of the
beneficiary is personal property only. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80; Ord. No. O-104-84, 1, 12-10-84)
Secs. 14-2--14-15. Reserved.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14 - REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURE ACT
14-2
ARTICLE II. DISCLOSURE OF INTERESTS
Sec. 14-16. Disclosures required.
Whenever any of the following having an interest in real estate, to wit: A corporation, partnership,
association, business trust, estate, two (2) or more persons having a joint or common interest, other commercial
or legal entity, trustee of a land trust, or any beneficiary or beneficiaries thereof make application to the village
for action requiring an ordinance or ordinance amendment, village board of trustees approval, or other village
agency approval, with respect to sale or purchase of said real estate, or zoning, annexation, vacation of streets
and alleys, leases and contracts with respect thereto, issuance by the village of industrial revenue bonds,
residential or housing revenue bonds, or similar revenue bonds, a disclosure notice in the form set forth in
section 14-36 shall be certified and attached to the application by said applicant or applicants.
In the case of corporation, all shareholders owning shares equal to or in excess of five (5) per cent of
the issued and outstanding capital stock of said corporation shall be disclosed on said disclosure notice.
Whenever any interest required to be disclosed hereunder is held by an agent or agents, or a nominee
or nominees, the principals for whom such agents or nominees hold such interest shall also be disclosed. The
application of a spouse or any other party, if constructively controlled by another person, or legal entity as set
forth above, shall state the name and address of such person or entity possessing such constructive control and
the relationship under which such control is being or may be exercised. Whenever any of the following is held
by a corporation, to wit: A stock interest required to be disclosed, a partnership interest, an interest in an
association or other legal entity or other beneficial interest, all shareholders of such corporation owning shares
equal to or in excess of five (5) per cent of all issued and outstanding capital stock of said corporation shall
also be disclosed. If such an interest is held by another legal entity, all individuals or beneficiaries owning five
(5) per cent or more of such entity shall be disclosed.
All disclosure notices and updated disclosure notices shall be filed with and retained in the custody of
the clerk. The clerk shall only accept such subject disclosure notices or updated disclosure notices for filing as
comply with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80; Ord. No. O-104-84, 2, 12-
10-84)
Sec. 14-17. Payments by village.
No monies may be paid out by the village until all disclosure notices are filed and the procedures of
section 14-16 are completed. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-18. Change in interest.
Before the final execution of the contract or during the term of any continuing contract between the
village and any person having an interest in real estate, or before the village takes final action on any
application described in section 14-16, if there is any change in any interest in the property of any party
disclosed in any disclosure notice, the person who transfers his interest and the persons obtaining the interest in
the real estate must file updated disclosure notices with the clerk within ten (10) days of any change; provided,
however, that this article is inapplicable to a change caused by death or bankruptcy. Failure to so file shall be a
violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-19. Contract voidable.
Any contract which is in violation of this chapter shall be voidable at the option of the village but only
on the grounds of a fraudulent failure to disclose or a wilfully inaccurate disclosure by a party prohibited by
law from having an interest in the contract or by another party conspiring with such a party to prevent
discovery of the prohibited interest. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14 - REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURE ACT
14-3
Sec. 14-20. Actions to compel filing.
Any person or persons may institute an action in any court of competent jurisdiction to compel the
filing of disclosure notices by any party or entity required to file the same under this chapter or to compel the
village to follow the procedures specified in this chapter. If the court finds that there is a party who is required
to file, and who is able to file but has not done so, or that the village has not followed the procedure specified
in this chapter, it shall order the appropriate parties to file or to procure the filing of such disclosure notices
upon penalty of contempt. The court may award reasonable attorneys' fees where warranted. (Ord. No. O-59-
80, 1, 7-14-80)
Secs. 14-21--14-35. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. DISCLOSURE NOTICES
Sec. 14-36. Description.
A disclosure notice shall contain the following:
(1) Name and address of disclosing party (including individual names as well as names of
business firms, partnerships, corporations);
(2) Brief description of the contract or condemnation case number and court, or the zoning,
special use variation or other proceeding under the zoning ordinance, as the case may be;
(3) Common street address of real estate or general description (including county);
(4) Legal description of real estate;
(5) Nature and extent of the interest (percentage of total) of the person(s) filing the notice;
(6) The name, address, legal nature and extent of interests of any and all persons deriving an
interest from or through the disclosing or filing party; and
(7) Each disclosure notice shall contain the following statement clearly visible to the person
disclosing:
"I swear (or affirm) that there are no other persons deriving any interest from or through me or
from or through any other person or entities above set forth in the property which is the
subject of the contract or application for which I am filing this disclosure notice whom I have
not disclosed. I understand that if there are any changes in the interest disclosed in this
disclosure notice during the terms of the subject contract or before the village has taken final
action on the matter for which this disclosure notice is filed, I shall file a subsequent
disclosure notice disclosing such changes."
(Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-37. Affirmation or swearing required.
A disclosure notice shall be affirmed or sworn to by the individual or individuals filing it. (Ord. No.
O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-38. To be public records.
All disclosure notices shall be public records. Any person requesting copies shall be promptly
furnished the same at a charge of twenty-five cents ($0.25) per page. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Secs. 14-39--14-50. Reserved.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14 - REAL ESTATE DISCLOSURE ACT
14-4
ARTICLE IV. CONDEMNATION PROCEEDINGS
Sec. 14-51. Disclosure notice.
In any condemnation proceeding instituted by the village, it shall be the duty of each defendant who
files an appearance or answer, to file a disclosure notice as described in section 14-36 within thirty (30) days
after his filing of said appearance or answer or prior to any order vesting an interest in the real estate in a
condemning body, whichever comes first. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-52. Refusal or failure to disclose.
The refusal or failure of any party to disclose in this chapter does not affect the taking of the property
by the village. The village, however, shall not pay the proceeds of the deposit to any person entitled to a
portion thereof because of his interest in real estate unless a disclosure notice has previously been filed by that
person. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Secs. 14-53--14-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. VIOLATION; PENALTY
Sec. 14-81. Additional information.
Notwithstanding any of the above provisions, the village may require any such additional information
as is reasonably necessary to achieve full disclosure relevant to the action under consideration by the village
president and board of trustees or other village agency. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-82. Failure to comply.
In the event of a failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the village president and board
of trustees or other village agency may refuse to act upon the application; or, if any ordinance, ordinance
amendment or other village action in connection with the real estate has been approved or taken, such approval
or other action shall be voidable at the option of the village. (Ord. No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
Sec. 14-83. Violation; penalty.
Any person required under this chapter to file the disclosures required hereunder who fails to do so or
who willfully furnishes false, inaccurate or incomplete information is guilty of a Class A misdemeanor. (Ord.
No. O-59-80, 1, 7-14-80)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14-1/2 - CONVEYANCE OF REAL ESTATE, ETC.
14.5-1
Chapter 14-1/2 CONVEYANCE OF REAL ESTATE OWNED BY THE VILLAGE*
----------
*Editor's note--Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, adopted May 14, 1984, added Ch. 14A to the Code, which
chapter the editor has redesignated Ch. 14 1/2 to conform to the system of numbering in the Code.
Cross reference(s)--Village board of trustees, 2-16 et seq.; real estate disclosure act, 14-1 et seq.;
eminent domain, 20-1 et seq.
----------
Art. I. In General, 14 1/2-1--14 1/2-4
Art. II. Deed of Conveyance, 14 1/2-5
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 14 1/2-1. Power to convey.
The board of trustees of the Village of Palatine has the power to direct the conveyance of any real
estate owned by the village when, in the opinion of the board, the real estate is no longer necessary,
appropriate, required for the use of, profitable to, or for the best interests of the village. This power shall be
exercised by an ordinance passed by three-fourths of the board of trustees then holding office, at any regular
meeting or at any special meeting called for that purpose. (Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, 5-14-84)
Sec. 14 1/2-2. Ordinance directing conveyance.
An ordinance directing the conveyance of real estate owned by the village shall specify the location of
the real estate, the use thereof, and such conditions with respect to further use of the real estate as the board of
directors may deem necessary and desirable to the public interest. (Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, 5-14-84)
Sec. 14 1/2-3. Publication of notice.
Except as hereinafter provided in section 14 1/2-4 hereof, before the board of trustees shall convey real
estate by virtue of the ordinance described in section 14 1/2-2, notice of the proposal to sell shall be published
once each week for three (3) successive weeks in a daily or weekly paper published in the village, or if there is
none, then in some paper published in Cook County. The first publication shall be not less than thirty (30) days
before the day provided in the notice for the opening of bids for the real estate. The notice shall contain an
accurate description of the property, state the purpose for which it is used and at what meeting the bids will be
considered and opened, and shall advertise for bids therefor. All such bids shall be opened only at a regular
meeting of the board of trustees. The board of trustees may accept the high bid or any other bid determined to
be in the best interest of the village by a vote of three-fourths of the members of the board then holding office,
but by a majority vote of those holding office, they may reject any and all bids. The consideration for such a
sale may include but need not be limited to the provision of off-street parking facilities by the purchaser, which
parking facilities may be made part of the municipal parking system. Such consideration also may include the
provision of other public facilities by the purchaser. (Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, 5-14-84)
Sec. 14 1/2-4. Authority to convey without publication.
If publication for bids fails to attract a bid acceptable to the board or if a majority of the members of
the board then holding office determines that publication of notice and advertising for bids would be futile for
any reason whatsoever, including but not limited to, matters concerning the condition or marketability of the
real estate, as the board in its sole discretion shall determine, the board may authorize and direct appropriate
municipal officers to negotiate the sale or other conveyance of real estate on behalf of the village without
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 14-1/2 - CONVEYANCE OF REAL ESTATE, ETC.
14.5-2
further publication. Such designated officers shall negotiate with any and all responsible persons or firms
expressing an interest in the real estate and shall submit promptly any firm proposals or offers to the board of
trustees of the village, who shall accept or reject the proposals or offers as provided in this Chapter 14 1/2.
(Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, 5-14-84)
ARTICLE II. DEED OF CONVEYANCE
Sec. 14 1/2-5. Conveyance of real estate.
When the ordinance described in section 14 1/2-1 has been adopted and the consideration paid or
secured, the president and the municipal clerk, may convey the real estate and transfer it, by proper deed of
conveyance, stating therein the consideration therefor, with the seal of the village. (Ord. No. O-30-84, 1, 5-
14-84)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 15- EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS
15-1
Chapter 15 EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS
----------
*Editor's note--Ord. No. O-31-88, 2, adopted March 14, 1988, repealed Ch. 15 in its entirety
pertaining to signs which derived from Code 1961, 27.201--27.226, 27.301--27.306, 27.401--27.404,
27.501--27.508, 27.601--27.606, 27.701--27.704, 27.801--27.804, 27.901--27.903; Ord. No. O-52-69, adopted
Sept. 22, 1969; Ord. No. O-91-76, 1, 2, adopted Oct. 11, 1976; Ord. No. O-96-76, 1, adopted Oct. 25,
1976; Ord. No. O-18-79, 3, adopted March 12, 1979; Ord. No. O-48-79, 1, adopted May 29, 1979; Ord.
No. O-100-82, 1--7, adopted Oct. 11, 1982 and Ord. No. O-85-84, 1, adopted Oct. 5, 1984.
----------
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 15.1 Definitions.
As used in this Section Article, unless the context otherwise requires:
Control Area means an electrical system bounded by interconnection (tie-line) metering and
telemetry. It controls generation directly to maintain its interchange schedule with other control areas and
contributes to frequency regulation of the interconnection.
Control Area Emergency means that Control Area is at risk of having to shed firm load, having
taken or committed to take all feasible mitigating action short of shedding firm load and firm sales.
"Controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service" means the implementation of a plan to curtail
electric service to firm load customers for a short period of time and rotating this curtailment of electric service
through different areas within the electric utility's service territory in a situation where the demand has
exceeded or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. The
action of an electric utility to interrupt or curtail electric service to a customer participating in or taking service
under an interruptible or curtailable rate is not included in this definition of a "controlled rotating interruption
of electric service."
Emergency energy plan means the portions of the Emergency load conservation procedures, which
immediately precede and include the controlled rotating interruption of electrical service to firm load customers
within the Village. The Emergency energy plan shall include the following steps:
(1) a request for emergency help from neighboring utilities;
(2) a declaration of a control area emergency;
(3) a public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use; and,
(4) implementation of the plan for controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service.
"Emergency load conservation procedures" means a planned course of action developed by an electric
utility company to be implemented in emergency situations when the demand for electricity exceeds, or is at
significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility.
"Electric utility company" or "electric utility" means any person or entity engaged in the business of
distributing, transmitting, or otherwise delivering electricity, regardless of its source, for use or consumption
within the Village. This term shall not include any person or entity that delivers electricity to fewer than 50
customers within the Village.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 15- EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS
15-2
Sec. 15.2 Submittal of emergency energy plan.
Every electric utility company must have adopted an emergency energy plan no later than 30 days after
the effective date of this chapter, or within 30 days after becoming an electric utility company, whichever is
later. Every such electric utility company shall submit to the Village Manager an emergency energy plan
adopted by the company no later than 30 days after the effective date of this chapter, or within 24 hours of the
time the plan is adopted, whichever is later. The electric utility company shall be required to examine and
update as needed its emergency energy plan at least annually. The electric utility company shall notify the
foregoing public official(s) in writing of any material revisions to its plan and the rationale for said revisions
within five (5) business days of the time said revisions are made.
The emergency energy plan shall include, at a minimum, information detailing:
(1) Circumstances that would require the implementation of the emergency energy plan;
(2) Stages of the emergency energy plan;
(3) The approximate geographic limits of each outage area provided for in the emergency energy
plan;
(4) The approximate number of customers within each outage area provided for in the emergency
energy plan;
(5) The police facilities, fire stations, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, day care centers, senior
citizen centers, community health centers, dialysis centers, community mental health centers,
correctional facilities, stormwater and wastewater treatment or pumping facilities, and waterpumping
stations that have been identified by the Village and persons on life-support systems
that are known to the company, and that could be affected by controlled rotating interruptions
of electric service under the emergency energy plan; and
(6) The anticipated sequence and duration of intentional interruptions of electric service to each
outage area under the emergency energy plan.
Sec. 15.3 Review of Plan.
(a) Upon submittal of the emergency energy plan to the Village, the Village shall review the
emergency energy plan in order to determine if the emergency energy plan is complete and to assure
appropriate coordination with public health and safety agencies. The Village may reject the emergency energy
plan if it does not contain all the information required under Section 15.2(b), in which case the Village shall
notify the electric utility company in writing of said rejection and the reasons therefor. The electric utility
company shall thereafter submit a complete emergency energy plan to the Village no later than thirty (30) days
after such notice is sent by the Village.
(b) The Village and the electric utility shall work cooperatively to:
(1) Identify customers and facilities for which a controlled rotating interruption of electric service
would require heightened response by Village public health and safety agencies,
(2) Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on public health and safety, and
(3) Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on the duties of the Village s public health and
safety agencies.
Sec. 15.4 Implementation of emergency energy plan.
(a) Whenever an electric utility company determines that it may be necessary to implement a
controlled rotating interruption of electrical service due to the demand for electricity exceeding, or being at
significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility company, the electric
utility company shall do the following:
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES - CHAPTER 15- EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS
15-3
(1) Take appropriate action in preparation for implementing a controlled rotating interruption of
electric service and notify the appropriate electric utility company personnel, and
(2) Notify the Village Manager that the electric utility company will be implementing its
emergency energy plan. The notification shall be made pursuant to a notification procedure
approved by the Village Council. The Village Manager may waive the notice requirement to
accommodate exigent circumstances.
(b) Subsequent to providing the notice as required above, an electric utility company shall reasonably
and separately advise the designated Village officials when it implements each of steps of the emergency
energy plan. Such steps shall include the following:
(1) A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities;
(2) A declaration of a control area emergency;
(3) A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use.
(c) The electric utility company shall give a separate notice to the Village Manager immediately upon
the determination that there will a controlled rotating interruption of electric service pursuant to the emergency
energy plan. The notification shall include the areas to be interrupted; the sequence and estimated duration of
the service outage for each area; and the affected feeders and number of affected customers in each area.
Whenever practical, the notification shall be made at least two hours prior to the time of the outages, and in no
case shall the notification be made less than 30 minutes prior to the outages, if the company is aware that
controlled rotating interruptions may be required.
(d) Notification required by this section shall be in addition to any notification requirements set forth
in any applicable franchise agreement or franchise ordinance, or as may be required by applicable Federal or
State law or regulation.
Sec. 15.5 Violations; enforcement.
Any electric utility company that knowingly violates this chapter or any rules promulgated thereunder
shall be subject to a fine of not less than $2,500 and not more than $10,000 for each offense. Each day that a
violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
The Village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or order to compel the
other party to comply with the provisions of this chapter.
Sec. 15.6 Construction.
Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed to preclude or interfere with the implementation by an
electric utility company of measures necessary to assure the provision of adequate, efficient, reliable and
environmentally safe service, as required by the Illinois Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.).
Nothing set forth in this Chapter shall be deemed to modify the terms of any existing franchise agreement or
franchise ordinance otherwise applicable to any electric utility company, or to excuse any performance required
by such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any authority that may be exercised pursuant to such agreement or
ordinance, or to limit any remedy that may be available under such agreement or ordinance.
Sec. 15.7 Severability.
Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this Chapter be declared invalid or
unconstitutional by a court or agency of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not
affect any of the remaining words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Chapter, since the
same would have been enacted by the Village Council without the incorporation in this Chapter of any such
invalid or unconstitutional word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Ord.No. 0-72-99; 2;6-14-99]
