ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 19-1. Bills.
Bills for water and sewer service shall be dated and sent out at such times as may be directed by the
mayor and village council.
All water and sewer bills must be paid within twenty-three (23) days after the statements are presented
or put in the mail and an additional ten (10) per cent shall be paid on all bills paid later. (Code 1961, §21.306;
Ord.No.0-80-89, §1, 6-28-99; Ord. No. 0-286-03, §1, 12-8-03)
Sec. 19-2. Termination of service for nonpayment.
The water supply may be shut off from any premises for which any bill or bills for water or sewer service
remain unpaid forty-two (42) days after such bill or bills are rendered. Such bill or bills for water or sewer
service shall include any and all services rendered by the village in performance of necessary repairs and
maintenance of the service pipes, meters or other equipment related to the water supply or sewer servicing the
subject premises, together with all filing fees, court costs and other charges incurred by the village in the
collection of said bill or bills. After settlement of the amount due on such bill or bills on terms satisfactory to
the village, the supply shall be turned on only upon payment of the amount due, plus a fee as set out in the Fee
Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances.
(Code 1961, §21.307; Ord. No. O-102-76, §1, 11-22-76; Ord. No. 0-30-93, 4-12-93; Ord. No. 0-80-99, §2, 6-
28-99; Ord. No. 0-286-03, §2 12-8-03; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §1, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-2
Sec. 19-3. Notice of delinquency.
Whenever a bill for water or sewer service, which service shall include any and all services rendered
by the village in the performance of necessary repair and maintenance of the service pipes, meters or other
equipment related to the water supply or sewer servicing the subject premises, remains unpaid ninety (90) days
after it has been rendered, the village clerk shall file with the county recorder of deeds of Cook County a
statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the following:
(1) A legal description of the subject premises sufficient for identification thereof;
(2) The amount of money due for such services;
(3) The date when such amount became delinquent; and
(4) A notice that the village claims a lien for said amount.
If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the village clerk has
notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the clerk,
whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of ninety (90) days after it has been rendered.
If a bill for water or sewer service to real estate is unpaid at the time the owner sells such real estate,
and no statement of lien claim has been filed by the village prior thereto, the village manager shall refer the
matter to a firm or agency specializing in collection work to pursue collection from the seller, and no efforts
shall be made to collect the amount due from the purchaser of said real estate. If the seller acquires other real
estate within the village, the amount of the unpaid bill shall be added to future billings for water and sewer
services to such other real estate. Nothing herein shall be deemed to relieve an owner who rents his premises to
others from liability for unpaid water bills for service to such premises. (Code 1961, §21.309; Ord. No. O-
102-76, §1, 11-22-76; Ord. No. O-17-84, §1, 3-26-84, Ord. No. 0-154-10, §2, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-4. Foreclosure of lien.
The village shall have the power to foreclose the lien for unpaid bill or bills for water or sewer charges,
including all filing fees, court costs and other charges incurred by the village in the collection of said bill or
bills, by suit in chancery in the circuit court of Cook County. Said lien shall be effective and may be foreclosed
against the subject premises whether or not the party or parties owning or occupying the premises are the same
as those who owned or occupied the premises at the time such service was rendered.
(Code 1961, §21.310; Ord. No. O-102-76, §1, 11-22-76)
Sec. 19-5. Payment of bills for water and sewer service.
Payment of bills for water and sewer service (and the collection of garbage) shall be made either
directly to the village or to those businesses or enterprises which have been appointed agents to receive such
payments on the village's behalf. (Ord. No. O-22-78, §2, 4-10-78)
Sec. 19-6. Applicability of this chapter to all users of the Palatine water and sewer system.
In the application and enforcement of any provision of this chapter applicable to water and sewer
services furnished by the village, unless specifically stated in section 19-42, the provisions of this chapter shall
be applicable to residents and nonresidents of the village. (Ord. No. O-27-81, §1, 3-23-81)
Sec. 19-7. Bad check processing fee.
See Chapter 1 General Provisions, Sec. 1-11. Reimbursement for Insufficient Fund Checks. (Ord.
No. O-54-82, §1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 0-46-97, §1, 4-14-97)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-3
Sec. 19-8. Credits and Refunds.
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Article, in order to permit sound fiscal planning and
budgeting by the Village, no user/consumer shall be entitled to a refund of, or credit for, a fee imposed under
this Article unless the user/consumer files a claim for refund or credit within one year after the date on which
the fee was paid or remitted with the Director of Finance.
Credits and refunds will only be made to the end user/consumer of services and not third parties or
subsequent user/consumers.
(Ord. No. 0-154-10, §3, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Secs. 19-9--19-15. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. WATER
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 19-16. Use during construction.
Prior to the issuance of any building permit, and before any water meter is installed as herein provided,
the contractor so constructing such building may be permitted to use the village water supply by paying a per
unit construction water fee which shall be as set out in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of
Ordinances. (Code 1961, §21.308; Ord. No. O-54-82, §2, 6-14-82; Ord. No. O-180-88, § 4, 12-27-88; Ord.
No. O-88-91, §2, 6-24-91 Ord.No. 0-49-94, §4-25-94)
Sec. 19-17. Turning on.
No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any persons
but the director of public works or some other person authorized by him to perform this service. (Code 1961,
§21.101)
Sec. 19-18. Application; fee.
Application to have water turned on shall be made to the Director of Community Services and by
doing so, the applicant agrees to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this chapter as condition governing
the use of the village water supply by the applicant. (Ord. No. 0-142-15 §1, 12/7/15)
(Editor’s note: Sec. 19-19. Deposit was removed by Ord. No. 0-80-99, 6/28/99 and therefore, Sec. 19-19.1
Water system development surcharge 19-19.1 was renumbered as 19-19.
On 12/7/15, Ord. No. 0-142-15 deleted Sec. 19-19 Water System development surcharge, in its entirety,
therefore Sec. 19-20 was renumbered to 19-19. Also, Sec. 19-21 Mileage charge for connection was deleted in
its entirety and Sec. 19-22 - 19-27 was renumbered to Sec. 19-20 – 19-25.)
Sec. 19-19. Connection and meter fees.
All water taps shall be made by and at the expense of the owner, subject to village inspection and
approval. For each such inspection the owner shall pay the village an inspection fee as set out in the Fee
Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. All materials for water taps shall be in accordance with
village specifications and supplied by the developer or owner. All water meters must be purchased and
installed by the village or village designee. Applications for water taps and water meters shall be made to the
Director of Community Services and the required fees paid at the time of such application. Fees for water
meters for new service, expansion of service, or replacement equipment shall be as set out in an amount not to
exceed the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. (Code 1961, §21.105; Ord. No. 0-18-79, §4,
3/12/79; Ord. No. 0-54-82, §4, 6/14/82; Ord. No. 0-180-88, §8, 12/27-88; Ord. No. 0-88-91, §5, 6/24/91; Ord.
No. 0-49-94 §3, 4/25/94; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §4 12/13/10, effective 1/1/11; Ord. No. 0-142-15, §1, 12/7/15;
Ord. No. 0-5-17, 1/16/17)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-4
Sec. 19-20. Resale prohibited; emergencies excepted.
No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the village supply to any premises
other than that for which application has been made and the water installed, except in case of emergency.
(Code 1961, §21.107)
Sec. 19-21. Tampering prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person, not authorized by the village, to tamper with, alter or injure any
part of the village water works or supply system, or any meter. (Code 1961, §21.108)
Sec. 19-22. Sewer flushing prohibited.
It shall be unlawful to use potable water for the flushing of sanitary sewers unless such flushing is
done with a high velocity type sewer jet. (Ord. No. O-131-77, §1, 12-12-77)
Sec. 19-23. Illegal connection.
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to connect any unit of property or portion
thereof to the village water system without obtaining a permit and paying the applicable fees as required under
this Article II. (Ord. No. O-19-81, §1, 2-23-81)
Sec. 19-24. Unauthorized draw of water.
Contractors wanting to draw water from a Village hydrant shall apply to the Department of Public
Works for a permit authorizing the drawing of water from a Village hydrant. The department shall require the
contractor to use a hydrant meter, rented from Public Works, as a condition to permitting the contractor to us
an unmetered hydrant. Provided, however, if the contractor is filling a tanker truck at the public works facility
from an already metered hydrant, then no hydrant meter rental is necessary. Fees for the water shall be as set
out in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. O-19-81, §1, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 0-
49-94 §4, 4-25-94; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §6, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-25. Penalty.
Any person, firm or corporation who connects a unit of property or portion thereof to the village water
system without having been issued a permit and paying all required fees, or who draws water from the village
water system without paying the required water rates, shall be fined an amount as set out in the Fee Schedule
Supplement to the Code of Ordinances and in addition shall pay to the village an amount equal to the
estimated cost of the water used as reasonably determined by the director of finance and operations. (Ord. No.
O-19-81, §1, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 0-5-98; §22, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 0-80-99, §4, 6-28-99; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §7,
12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Secs. 19-26 - 19-35. Reserved.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-5
DIVISION 2. SERVICE PIPES
Sec. 19-36. Installation to be at cost of owner; director of public works to supervise.
All service pipes from the watermain to the premises to be served shall be installed by, and at the cost
of the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. Such installations shall be under the
supervision of the director of public works. (Code 1961, §21.201; Ord. No. 0-142-15, §1, 12/7/15)
Sec. 19-37. Specifications.
All water service pipes from the main to the meter shall be not less than one inch in size. Only copper
pipes or tubing shall be used to connect the meter with the mains. All fittings and connections shall be uniform
and comply with specifications established by the Mayor and Village Council.
All service pipes shall be buried at least five (5) feet deep in the ground. (Code 1961, §21.102; Ord.
No. O-54-82, §5, 6-14-82)
Sec. 19-38. Maintenance and repairs.
The village shall maintain the water service pipes from the water main up to and including the
roundway and shutoff boxes. The owner shall be liable for all maintenance and repairs of the water service
pipes from the roundway to the water meter. The village shall be responsible for the maintenance and repairs of
water meters. The property owner shall be liable for any damage to the water meter by any person or workman
hired by the owner on his property. The property owner shall be responsible for keeping any debris from
entering and damaging the shutoff box. (Code 1961, §21.203; Ord. No. O-54-82, §6, 6-14-82; Ord. No. O-72-
83, §1, 10-24-83)
Sec. 19-39. Excavations.
Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the
ordinance provisions relating to excavations in streets. (Code 1961, §21.204)
Sec. 19-40. Shutoff boxes.
Shutoff or service boxes shall be placed on every service pipe, and shall be located between the curb
line and the sidewalk line where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily
accessible, and shall be protected from frost. (Code 1961 §21.205)
Sec. 19-41 Abandonment
If an existing water service is no longer to be used for its intended purpose as in the case of the demolition
of a building, the water service pipe shall be disconnected at the corporation stop or at another location
approved by the Director of Public Works. The corporation stop can remain provided there is no leakage when
closed. The b-box is to be removed and the hole properly backfilled and restored. The owner of the property or
the applicant is responsible for all costs and restoration associated with the disconnection. This disconnection
must be inspected and approved by the Director of Public Works or his designee. Ord. No. 0-61-04, §1, 4-12-
04)
Secs. 19-42-19-50. Reserved.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-6
DIVISION 3. METERS
Sec. 19-51. Required; charges pending installation.
All premises using water from the village water supply must be supplied with a Village supplied meter
paid for by the property owner when service is obtained or altered authorized by building permit. The charge
for such meters shall be as set out in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances.
All non-residential building units must convert to an Automated Meter Read (AMR) meter for
continued water service. Any residential premises not converting from a manually read meter to an Automated
Meter Read (AMR) meter after due notice of such conversion being tendered shall pay a non-conversion fee
for each billing cycle as set out in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances until such time that
the meter conversion occurs. Said fee may be prorated should the conversion occur within a billing cycle.
(Code 1961, §21.301; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §9, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11; Ord. No. 0-89-15, §1, 08-03-15)
Sec. 19-52. Location.
Meters and remote meter reading devices shall be installed by the village in a location that will provide
operability and be easy to access. (Code 1961, §21.302; Ord. No. 0-286-03, §4 12-8-03; Ord. No. 0-89-15, §1,
08-03-15)
Sec. 19-53 Access to Meter and External Transponder
No person shall prevent or deny any access to any authorized village employee or any village
authorized designee attempting to read, inspect, repair, convert or replace any water meter or external
transponder. In the event access to the meter or transponder is denied, or the area around the water meter or
external transponder is altered to limit access to prevent the repair or maintenance of Village owned equipment,
the Director of Public Works shall notify the owner in writing of required access. If the condition is not
remedied within thirty (30) days after the date such notice is issued, the water supply may be shut off, and shall
remain so until the condition has been remedied. (Code 1961, §21.303; Ord. No. O-27-81, §2, 3-23-81; Ord.
No. O-54-82, §7, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 0-80-99, §5, 6-28-99; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §10, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11;
Ord. No. 0-89-15, §1, 08-03-15)
Sec. 19-54 Water Meter Testing
Any customer who disputes the accuracy of the meter serving their property may request that such
meter be tested. Upon payment to the village of a testing fee, as set forth in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the
Code of Ordinances, the disputed meter will be removed and replaced with a like type meter by representatives
of the village, and in the company of the person so requesting the testing, the meter will be delivered to a
testing facility designated by the village. In the presence of the person so requesting the test, the meter will be
tested in accordance with the American Water Works Association Meter Testing Procedures. If, after such
testing, the meter proves to be within limits set forth by the American Water Works Association, the fee paid
shall be retained by the Village to cover the cost of removal, testing and reinstallation of the meter. If, after
such testing, the meter over records in aggregate amount exceeding limits defined by the American Water
Works Association Meter Testing Procedures, the meter shall be replaced at no cost to the customer, and the
testing fee shall be refunded in full.
Except as provided in this chapter, meters shall be tested and/or replaced at village expense, unless
said meter has sustained damages due to abuse, tampering or negligence.
Replaced meters are not eligible for customer requested testing for 180 calendar days after original
installation.
(Ord. No. 0-89-15, §1, 08-03-15)
Secs. 19-55-19-60. Reserved.

DIVISION 4. RATES AND CHARGES

Sec. 19-61. Payment prerequisite to service.
No premises shall be served with water from the municipal water supply, nor served by or connected
with the municipal sanitary sewer system unless the rates hereinafter designated shall be paid. The Village, at
its sole option, may bill a tenant or other occupant; however, it shall be the ultimate responsibility of the owner
of all premises so served to pay the charges herein prescribed. (Code 1961, §21.304; Ord. No. O-19-76, §1, 3-
8-76; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §11, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-62. Water Rates
There shall be water charges pursuant to the classifications in this section.
A “user/consumer” is defined as a residential dwelling unit, commercial unit, business unit, industrial
unit, educational unit, governmental unit, institutional unit, or any other occupiable unit or combination
thereof, having direct access and use of water and/or sewer services regardless of whether water is or is not
metered through a single master meter. A residential dwelling unit is defined as any building or portion thereof
that contains living facilities, including provisions for sleeping, eating, and sanitation. Unit counts for
commercial, business, industrial or institutional uses shall be determined on an individual analysis of occupied
or common areas having direct access to water services. Water provided as a general service to common area
will be counted as one unit under this definition when determining the total direct access units regardless of the
number of direct distribution users. (Ord. No. 0-89-15, §1, 08-03-15)

effective 1-1-10; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §12, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)

rates:

Sec. 19-63. Sewer Service Rates
There shall be sewer charges pursuant to the classifications in this section based upon the consumption
of water where water is metered, consumption where a sewer meter is used, or a flat fee if neither water nor
sewer is metered.

Sec. 19-64. Local Capital Financing (Sewer Separation) Surcharge Rate
The local capital financing surcharge will be computed to allocate the annual financing costs of all
capital improvements to the sewer system over all those affected sewer system user/consumers of the village. It
shall be based upon their proportional benefits received as determined by the Village Council based upon the
number of sewer connections servicing the property.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-10
Each affected user/consumer shall be charged a flat monthly rate as set out in the Fee Schedule
Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. 0-205-06, §1, 12/4/06, effective 1-1-07; Ord. 0-211-07, §1, 12-
10-07, effective 1-1-08; Ord. 0-171-08, §1, 12-1-08, effective 1-1-09; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §22, 12-13-10,
effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-65. Local Storm Water Drainage Facility Surcharge Rate
The local storm water drainage facility maintenance surcharge will be computed to allocate the annual
maintenance cost of storm water drainage facilities accepted for maintenance by the Village to those lots served
by such facilities. The charge per lot to be established by the Village Council at the time such facility is
accepted by the Village. The charge is subject to adjustment upon an annual review by the Department of
Finance and Operations.
Each affected user/consumer of the Fair Meadows Drainage Facility shall be charged a flat monthly rate
as set out in the Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 0-154-10, §23, 12-13-10,
effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-66 Flood Control Surcharge Rate
The flood control surcharge will be computed to allocate the annual financing costs of certain flood
control improvements designated by the Mayor and Village Council (as amended from time to time) and
generally consistent with resolution adopted by the Corporate Authorities (R-53-02) or any amendments
thereto. The surcharge shall consist of a monthly charge imposed upon each residential, commercial, industrial
and institutional unit located within the incorporated limits of the Village. For purposes of this surcharge, a
“unit” shall be defined as each utility customer within the incorporated limits of the Village.
The surcharge is subject to adjustment and/or abatement by the Village Council based upon an annual
review by the Department of Finance and Operations.
Each affected user/consumer shall be charged a flat monthly rate as set out in the Fee Schedule
Supplement to the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. #0-212-07, §1, 12-10-07, effective 11-08; Ord. No. 0-154-10,
§24, 12-13-10, effective 1-1-11)
Sec. 19-67. General provisions regarding rates and charges.
(1) Bills. Said rates or charges for service shall be payable in accordance with Chapter 19 of the Code of
Ordinances, Village of Palatine, Illinois.
(2) Revenues. All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the water and sewer system shall
be deposited in the appropriate accounts of the water fund and sewer fund. All such revenues and moneys shall
be held by the authorized village official and other duly authorized employees of the village separate and apart
from other funds of the village and deposited in the accounts of the funds designated as the "water fund” and
the “sewerage fund” of village.
(3) Accounts. The authorized village official shall establish a property system of accounts and shall keep
proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions
relative to the water and sewer system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an
independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of both the water and sewer
systems.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-11
(4) Notice of rates. A copy of this section properly certified by the authorized village official shall be
filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real
estate of the charges of the sewerage system of said village on their properties.
(5) Penalty. Shall be in accordance with Chapter 1 of the Code of Ordinances, Village of Palatine,
Illinois.
(6) Access to records. The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or the United States Environmental
Protection Agency or their authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers, and
records of the village which are applicable to the village system of user charges for the purpose of making
audit, examination, excerpts, and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and
general conditions to any state or federal grant.

DIVISION 5. SPRINKLING REGULATIONS*
----------
*Editor's note--Ordinance No. O-19-90, § 1, adopted Feb. 26, 1990, deleted §§19-71--19-73, which
were the substantive provisions of Art. II, Div. 5, which pertained to sprinkling regulations, and which derived
from Ord. No. O-77-86, §1, adopted July 28, 1986. Ord. No. O-19-90 also added new provisions, similar in
subject matter, set out as a new Div. 5 to Art. II.
----------
Sec. 19-71. Regulation of sprinkling.
(a) Sprinkling or watering lawns shall be prohibited from noon until 6:00 p.m. each day, from 12:01
a.m. on May 15 of each year until 11:59 p.m. on September 15 of each year and shall not occur on consecutive
days. For the purpose of this section, "lawn" shall be that portion of any land under cultivation with grass,
trees, shrubs, bushes or types of vegetation not occupied by the principal or accessory building. (Ord. No. 0-
103-15, §1, 9/8/15)
(b) The use of water from the village water system for purposes of sprinkling or watering lawns and for
certain other purposes, including, but not limited to, the filling of swimming pools and the noncommercial
washing of cars, is not essential to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the Village of Palatine. The
village manager is empowered to determine if other uses not specified in this section are nonessential.
(c) The village manager is authorized and empowered to impose additional restrictions, including
imposition of an odd/even water use cycle based on address and calendar day, of the nonessential use of water
from the village water system for such period of time and in such manner as he may deem necessary in order to
conserve the supply of water in the Village of Palatine. The village manager shall announce the restrictions
and the restrictions are effective upon the announcement. Upon announcing the restrictions, the village
manager shall report the nature of those restrictions and the reasons for them to the village president and board
of trustees. (Ord. No. O-19-90, §1, 2-26-90)
(d) Temporary 14 day sprinkling permits may be issued by the Director of Public Works to individuals
who have special needs related to newly installed landscape materials. (Ord. No. 0-115-12, §1, 8/6/12)
Secs. 19-72--19-80. Reserved.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-12
ARTICLE III. SEWERS*
----------
*Editor's note--Section 3 of Ord. No. O-102-84, adopted Nov. 26, 1984 deleted Art. III in its entirety
and enacted in lieu thereof a new Art. III as herein set forth. Former Art. III, consisting of §§19-81--19-87,
pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from the following: Code 1961, §§9.123, 20.401--20.405;
Ord. No. O-85-75, §1, adopted Nov. 24, 1975; Ord. No. O-27-81, § 4, adopted Mar. 23, 1981; and Ord. No.
O-54-82, §8, adopted June 14, 1982.
Cross reference(s)--Department of public works to have charge of construction and care, §2-173.
----------
Sec. 19-81. Definitions.
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as
follows:
(1) Federal government:
(a) Federal Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) as
amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 (Public Law 92-
500) and (Public Law 93-243).
(b) Administrator means the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
(c) Federal grant shall mean the U.S. government participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II, Grants for Construction of
Treatment Works, of the Act and implementing regulations.
(2) State government:
(a) State Act means the Code of Illinois Antipollution Bond Act of 1970.
(b) Director means the director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
(c) State grant shall mean the State of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of
treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Antipollution Bond Act and for making such
grants as filed with the secretary of the State of Illinois.
(3) Local government:
(a) Ordinance means this article.
(b) Village means the Village of Palatine.
(c) Authorized village official shall mean the village manager or his designated representative.
(4) Person shall mean any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual, firm,
company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency,
or other entity.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-13
(5) NPDES permit means any permit or equivalent document issued by the administrator, or, where
appropriate, by the director, after enactment of the Federal Water Pollution Control Amendments of 1972, to
regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the Federal Act.
(6) Wastewater and its characteristics:
(a) Wastewater shall mean the spent water of a community, including but not limited to, a
combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings,
industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and
stormwater that may be present.
(b) Sewage is used interchangeably with wastewater.
(c) Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the applicable effluent criteria.
(d) ppm shall mean parts per million by weight.
(e) Milligrams per liter shall mean a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent.
It is 0.001 grams of the constituent in 1,000 milliliters of water.
(f) Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in
water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device.
Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures
set forth in Standards Methods.
(g) BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days
at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
(h) pH shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration
expressed by one of the procedures outlined in Standard Methods.
(i) Standard Methods shall mean the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most
recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published
jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association,
and the Water Pollution Control Federation.
(j) Garbage shall mean solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking,
and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sale of produce.
(k) "Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried
freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater
than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension.
(l) Floatable oil is oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from
wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be
considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not
interfere with the collection system.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-14
(m) Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a
treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one hundred (100) gallons of sewage
per day, containing 0.17 pounds (200 mg/l) of BOD, and 0.20 pounds (240 mg/l) of
suspended solids.
(n) Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of
any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than
fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration
or flows during normal operation.
(o) Industrial waste shall mean any solid, liquid, or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to
flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial, or business establishment
or process or from the development, recovery, or processing of any natural resource as distinct
from sanitary sewage.
(p) Major contributing industry shall mean an industrial user of the publicly-owned treatment
works that: (a) has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average work day; or
(b) has a flow greater than ten (10) per cent of the flow carried by the municipal system
receiving the waste; or (c) has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in
standards issued under Section 307(a) of the Federal Act.
(7) Sewer types and appurtenances:
(a) Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids,
including storm, surface, and ground water drainage.
(b) Public sewer shall mean a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the village. It
shall also include sewers within or outside the village boundaries that serve one or more
persons and ultimately discharge into the village sanitary sewer system, even though those
sewers may not have been constructed with village funds.
(c) Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination
of both, and into which storm, surface, and ground waters or unpolluted industrial wastes are
not intentionally admitted.
(d) Storm sewer shall mean a sewer that carries storm, surface, and ground water drainage but
excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water.
(e) Combined sewer shall mean a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater,
storm, surface, and ground water drainage.
(f) Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other
place of disposal.
(g) Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives
the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and
conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five (5) feet
outside the inner face of the building wall.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-15
(h) Stormwater runoff shall mean that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers.
(i) Sewerage shall mean the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation, and pumping of sewage.
(j) Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
(8) Treatment:
(a) Pretreatment shall mean the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into
the wastewater treatment works.
(b) Wastewater treatment works shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating
wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste
treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant."
(9) Wastewater facilities shall mean the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry
away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse.
(10) Watercourse and connections:
(a) Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or
intermittently.
(b) Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of
surface or ground water.
(11) User types:
(a) User class shall mean the type of user either residential or commercial (nonindustrial) or
industrial as defined herein.
(b) Residential or commercial or nonindustrial user shall mean any user of the treatment works
not classified as an industrial user or excluded as an industrial user as provided for in this
paragraph.
(c) Industrial user shall mean any nongovernmental user of publicly-owned treatment works
identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and
Budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions:
(1) Division A--Agriculture, forestry, and fishing.
(2) Division B--Mining.
(3) Division D--Manufacturing.
(4) Division E--Communications, electric, gas, sanitary services and transportation.
(5) Division I--Services.
A user in the divisions listed above may be excluded if it is determined by the authorized
village official that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes from
sanitary conveniences.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-16
(d) Inspection manhole shall mean a structure located on a site where required by the
Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago. The purpose of an inspection manhole is to
provide access for the Metropolitan Sanitary District to sample and/or measure discharges.
The manhole shall be designed in accordance with Metropolitan Sanitary District criteria.
(12) Types of charges:
(a) Wastewater service charge shall be the charge per quarter or month levied on all users of the
wastewater system. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in Chapter 19, section
19-62 of the Code of Ordinances, Village of Palatine, Illinois and shall consist of the total of
the basic user charge, and the local capital financing surcharge, if applicable, and the local
storm drainage facility surcharge, if applicable.(Ord.No.O-146-93,11-22-93)
(b) Basic user charge shall mean the basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer
system.
(c) Local capital financing surcharge shall mean the assessment in addition to the basic user
charge for the payment of sewer construction debt service charges of principal, interest, and
other loan related costs to be charged based upon water usage and proportional benefits
received as determined by the village board for each sewer service on each property.
(d) Replacement shall mean expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or
appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain
the capacity and performance for which such were designed and constructed. The term
"operation and maintenance" includes replacement.
(e) Useful life shall mean the estimated period during which the collection system and/or
treatment works will be operated.
(f) Water and sewer fund is the principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the
operation of the water and sewer system.
(g) Local storm water drainage facility surcharge shall mean an assessment in addition to the
basic user charge for the construction or maintenance of local storm water drainage or
management facilities, and for payment of debt service charges on principal, interest and other
loan debt related cost to be charged on a per lot basis. A map of any area subject to such
charge and a listing of the per property charge on lots benefited by the facilities shall be on
file with the Clerk, following adoption by ordinance. (Ord. No O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84; Ord.
No.O-146-93, §3, 11-22-93)
Sec. 19-82. Use of public sewers required.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to place deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary
manner on public or private property within the Village of Palatine or in any area under the jurisdiction of said
village, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste.
(2) It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the Village of Palatine, or in any area
under jurisdiction of said village, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has
been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-17
(3) Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault,
septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
(4) The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment,
recreation, or other purposes situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in
which there is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary sewer of the village, is hereby
required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the
proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within ninety (90) days after date of
official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within two hundred fifty (250) feet (76.2 meters) of
the property line.

sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system approved by the Village of Palatine Department
of Health. When a public sanitary sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer
within ninety (90) days. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84)
Sec. 19-83. Connection fees.
It shall be unlawful to connect any sewer line serving any premises to any sewer main of the village
without first securing a permit therefor and paying the fee herein provided. The fees for such connections shall
be as provided in the fee schedule supplement to the Palatine Code of Ordinances.
The applicant shall furnish all labor and materials required for installing sewer service from the main to the
premises to be served.
Applications for connection permits shall conform to the general ordinances relating to applications for
permits, and no such permit shall be issued until the permit fee is paid. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84;
Ord. No. O-180-88, §10, 12-27-88; Ord. No. O-88-91, §7, 6-24-91; Ord. No. O-41-96, §1, 3-25-96)
Sec. 19-84. Building sewers and connections.
(1) No person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any
public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the authorized village
official.
(2) All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except those discharges in compliance
with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Act and more stringent state and local standards.
(3) There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: (a) for residential and commercial service,
and (b) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall
make application on a special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by
any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the authorized village
official. A permit and inspection fee as established by the village for a residential or commercial building sewer
permit shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. The industrial user, as a condition of
permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type
of activity.
(4) A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can
be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage system, including sewers, pump stations, and wastewater
treatment system, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional
anticipated waste load.

19-18
(5) All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be
borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the village from any loss or damage that may directly or
indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer.
(6) A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where
one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be
constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from
the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer.
(7) Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on

specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of
Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois shall apply. In
case of conflict, the provisions of the applicable village code shall take priority.
(9) Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at or below the elevation of

with this chapter and discharged to the building sewer.
(10) No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway
drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is
connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
(11) The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of
the building and plumbing code, or other applicable rules and regulations of the village, in the absence of
village rules or regulations, the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of
Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications
for Water and Sewer Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any
deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the authorized village official
before installation.
(12) The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the authorized village official when the
building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under
the supervision of the authorized village official.
(13) All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and
lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed
in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-
26-84)
(14) The owner of the building or property served by sewer shall be responsible for the maintenance
and repair of the building sewer up to and including the connection to the main. (Ord. No. 0-61-04, §2, 4-12-
04)

19-19
(15) If an existing building sewer is no longer to be used for its intended purpose as in case of the

Sec. 19-85. Use of the public sewers.
(1) No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, ground water,
roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any
sanitary sewer.
(2) Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically
designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the authorized village official. Industrial cooling
water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, to a storm sewer, or natural outlet on approval of the
authorized village official and permitted by the individual NPDES stormwater discharge permit. (Ord. No. 0-
41-04, §1, 3-8-04)
(3) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or
wastes to any public sewers:
(a) Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
(b) Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient
quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any
sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance,
or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
(c) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other corrosive property
capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage
works.
(d) Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the
flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as,
but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails
and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders.
(4) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials,
waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the authorized village official that such wastes can harm
either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or
can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the
acceptability of these wastes, the authorized village official will give consideration to such factors as the
quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the
sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of
wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances
which may be prohibited are:
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-20
(a) Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees
Fahrenheit (65 degrees centigrade).
(b) Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials, or oils, whether emulsified or
not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or
become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees
Fahrenheit (0 and 65 degrees Centigrade).
(c) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any
garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or
greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the authorized village official.
(d) Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating
solutions whether neutralized or not.
(e) Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or
toxic substance, or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any
such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the
limits established by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago for such
materials.
(f) Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such
concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the Metropolitan Water
Reclamation District of Greater Chicago as necessary after treatment of the composite sewage,
to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such
discharge to the receiving waters.
(g) Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits
established by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago in compliance
with applicable state or federal regulations.
(h) Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5.
(i) Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as
permitted by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago in compliance
with applicable state and federal regulations.
(j) Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/I at any time except as permitted by the Metropolitan
Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago in compliance with applicable state and
federal regulations.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-21
(k) Materials which exert or cause:
1. Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers
earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited
to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate);
2. Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning
solutions);
3. Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities
as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works;
4. Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined
herein.
(l) Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by
the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree
that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
(m) Any waters or wastes having: (1) a five-day BOD greater than three hundred (300) parts per
million by weight, or (2) containing more than three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by
weight of suspended solids, or (3) having an average daily flow greater than two (2) per cent
of the average sewage flow of the city, or (4) having wastewater concentrations greater than
normal as determined by sampling and testing of a user's wastewater discharge, shall be
subject to the review of the authorized village official. Where necessary in the opinion of the
authorized city representative, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary
treatment as may be necessary to: (1) reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to three hundred
(300) parts per million by weight, or (2) reduce the suspended solids to three hundred fifty
(350) parts per million by weight, or (3) control the quantities and rates of discharge of such
waters or wastes. Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to
proposed preliminary treatment system shall be submitted for the approval of the authorized
village official and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until said approvals
are obtained in writing.
(5) If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which
waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in paragraph (4) of this section, or
which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in paragraph (4) of this section, and/or which
are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 CFR 403, June 26, 1978, and any amendments
thereto, and which in the judgment of the authorized village official, may have a deleterious effect upon the
sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or
constitute a public nuisance, the authorized village official may:
(a) Reject the wastes;
(b) Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers;
(c) Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
(d) Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating the wastes not covered by
existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions of paragraph (2) of this section. If the
authorized village official permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design
and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the
authorized village official and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances,
and laws.

19-22
(6) Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the authorized village

(7) Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained

(9) The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide

The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as
stipulated by the Metropolitan Sanitary District, but no less than once per year the industrial user must supply a
complete analysis of the constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal,
state, and local standards are being met. The industrial user shall comply with all requirements of the
Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago with respect to such tests and shall bear the
expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the Metropolitan Sanitary District.
(10) All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of water and wastes to which reference
is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the
Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be
determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the
event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest
downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall
be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and
to. determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property.
(11) No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or
arrangement between the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and any industrial
concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the Metropolitan
Water Reclamation District for treatment, subject to payment therefor, in accordance with any resolution or
ordinance establishing rates and charges passed by the village board, by the industrial concern, provided such
payments are in accordance with federal and state guidelines for user charge system. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3,
11-26-84)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-23
Sec. 19-86. Protection of sewer works from damage.
No person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, or tamper with any
structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision
shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84)
Sec. 19-87. Powers and authority of inspectors.
(1) The authorized village official and other duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials
and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation,
measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The authorized village
official or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical,
chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind
and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or system for waste treatment.
(2) While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in paragraph (1) above, the
authorized village official or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection
Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the owner and occupant and the owner and occupant shall be held harmless for injury or death
to the village employees and the village shall indemnify the owner or occupant against loss or damage to its
property by village employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage
asserted against the owner and occupant and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as
such may be caused by negligence, or failure of the owner and occupant to maintain safe conditions as required
in section 19-85(8).
(3) The authorized village official and other duly authorized employees of the village bearing proper
credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds
an easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair,
and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent
work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84)
Sec. 19-88. Penalties.
(1) Any person found to be violating any provision of this article except section 19-86 shall be served
by the village with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for
the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice,
permanently cease all violations. The village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any
violation of any provision of this article.
(2) Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in paragraph (1)
above, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined an amount as set out in the
Fee Schedule Supplement to the Code of Ordinances for each violation. Each day in which any violation shall
continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord.No. 0-5-98, §23, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 0-154-10, §25, 12-13-
10, effective 1-1-11)
(3) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the village by
reason of such violation. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-24
Sec. 19-89. Traps required.
It shall be unlawful to permit the use of or use any connection with the sanitary sewer unless the flow
from such connections passes through a catch basin, grease trap, or other interceptor in the manner required by
the general ordinances of the village relating to plumbing and sewers. (Ord. No. O-102-84, §3, 11-26-84)
Sec. 19-90. Injury to system prohibited.
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to flow into the sanitary sewer system any substance of any kind
which interferes with or prevents the functioning of the sewage disposal plant of the village. (Ord. No. O-102-
84, §3, 11-26-84)
Secs. 19-91--19-100. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. SEPTIC TANKS
Sec. 19-101. Plumbing requirements.
Each building or structure in the village used for residence, business, trade, industry or meeting
purposes shall be equipped with properly constructed and installed adequate sewage disposal facilities
connected with the village sanitary sewer system when such system can reasonably be extended to serve the
premises. Applications for septic tank permits must be made to the president and board. The plumbing in all
such places shall conform to the ordinances of the village and the laws of the state relative thereto. (Code
1961, §20.301)
Sec. 19-102. Tank required.
Any premises not connected with the sanitary sewer system shall be equipped with an adequate septic
tank having a capacity of not less than five hundred (500) gallons for each seven (7) or less persons living or
working in such place; and an additional seventy-five (75) gallons for each person in excess of seven (7);
provided that the tank in any premises used for meeting purposes shall have a capacity of not less than one
thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons. (Code 1961, §20.302).
Sec. 19-103. Specifications.
Each tank shall be located at least twenty (20) feet from any building and five (5) feet from a lot line,
and shall be constructed of twelve (12) gauge steel, monolithic concrete or brick or concrete blocks adequately
coated inside so as to be impervious to water. A baffle shall be located at the inlet end of the septic tank, six (6)
inches away from the inlet pipe, and shall extend from a point eight (8) inches above the liquid level to a point
nine (9) inches below the liquid level. At the outlet end a baffle shall be constructed five (5) inches from the
outlet and shall extend from a point six (6) inches above the liquid level to a point twelve (12) inches below the
liquid level.
These baffles shall be made of two (2) inch planks. Each tank must be equipped with a manhole or
similar cover opening to permit inspection and cleaning.
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-25
The tank shall be similar and equal to the design of septic tanks to serve single family dwellings
prepared by the Division of Sanitary Engineering, Cook County Public Health, copies of which are on file with
the clerk. (Code 1961, §20.303)
Sec. 19-104. Disposal field.
Each tank shall discharge the liquid through a vitrified bell and spigot tile with cement joints laid with
a grade of one (1) foot per one hundred (100) feet. This tile shall discharge into a concrete distribution box of
sufficient size to accommodate the necessary number of lateral lines of tile. The minimum size of this box shall
be eighteen (18) inches by eighteen (18) inches inside.
The disposal field tile shall be located at least seventy-five (75) feet distant from any well, ten (10) feet
from the tank, thirty (30) feet from any building used for human habitation, and shall not be closer than five (5)
feet from any lot line. Each lateral of the disposal field tile shall be connected separately to the distribution box,
and shall not be subdivided.
There shall be at least fifty (50) feet of disposal field tile for each person living or working in the
building, but in no case shall the total length of disposal field tile be less than two hundred (200) lineal feet.
The disposal field tile shall be four (4) inch drain tile laid with open joints at a maximum slope not to
exceed six (6) inches per one hundred (100) feet. The top half of the joint shall be covered with pieces of
asphalt treated paper to prevent absorption material from entering the tile. (Code 1961, §20.304)
Sec. 19-105. Trench.
The disposal field tile shall be laid in a trench of a minimum width of twenty-four (24) inches and a
maximum width of thirty-six (36) inches depending upon the depth of the tile below the ground line. The
maximum depth shall not be greater than thirty-six (36) inches.
The tile shall be laid on a minimum of six (6) inches of coarse gravel which shall extend for the entire
width of the trench and shall be covered with coarse gravel to a depth of at least two (2) inches above the top of
the tile. The balance of the trench shall be earthbackfill, well tamped. (Code 1961, §20.305)
Sec. 19-106. Inspection.
No septic tank or any pipes leading to or from the same shall be covered unless and until such tank and
pipes have been inspected and found to be in compliance with the ordinances of the village and with the state
laws pertaining thereto. (Code 1961, §20.306)
Sec. 19-107. Facilities required.
It shall be unlawful to use or occupy any premises as habitations, or for business, trade, industry or
meeting purposes in the village unless such premises are equipped with sewage disposal facilities consisting of
either a connection with a sanitary sewer system or a proper septic tank, as provided by ordinance. (Code
1961, §20.307)
PALATINE CODE OF ORDINANCES – CHAPTER 19 – UTILITY SERVICES
19-26
Sec. 19-108. Seepage tests.
Before any septic tanks and drain tile fields are constructed in any area within the village limits, a
seepage test shall be run in accordance with the requirements of the State Plumbing Code of 1959 promulgated
by the State Department of Health. The seepage trench shall be constructed to function in the type of soil
present, as prescribed in such specifications. (Code 1961, §20.308)

Editor’s Note: A new Article V Stormwater Discharge was enacted by Ord. 0-41-04, passed on March 8,
2004.
